title: 113_hr2624
content: The Act titled "Child Trafficking Victims Protection Act" aims to protect child trafficking victims. The "Child Trafficking Victims Protection Act" mandates training for personnel interacting with unaccompanied alien children and ensures their care and transportation during immigration proceedings. The "Child Trafficking Victims Protection Act" requires unaccompanied alien children to be transferred to the Office of Refugee Resettlement within 72 hours of apprehension, with female officers present during transport. The Secretary must provide trained staff and resources at Customs and Border Protection ports of entry and stations, including child welfare officials. Child welfare professionals will be hired to assist at U.S. Customs and Border Protection offices with high numbers of unaccompanied alien child apprehensions. These professionals must have expertise in culturally competent, trauma-centered, and developmentally appropriate interviewing skills. Child welfare professionals hired to assist at U.S. Customs and Border Protection offices will develop treatment guidelines, conduct screenings, notify relevant departments, and interview adult relatives of unaccompanied alien children. The Office of Refugee Resettlement conducts family relationship and trafficking assessments for unaccompanied alien children, ensuring they receive necessary medical and mental health care while in the custody of U.S. Customs and Border Protection. Unaccompanied alien children in custody are provided with necessary items such as clothing, hygiene products, bedding, nutrition, a safe living environment, and access to recreational activities if held for more than 24 hours. Unaccompanied alien children in custody are provided with necessary items, access to legal services, consular officials, and supervised phone calls to family members. The Office of Refugee Resettlement submits final determinations on family relationships to the Secretary for consideration of community-based support alternatives to detention. The Secretary is required to submit a report to Congress on screening procedures used by child welfare professionals for unaccompanied children. The Secretary must notify the Office of Refugee Resettlement within 48 hours of encountering an unaccompanied alien child for transfer and placement coordination. Unaccompanied alien children must be provided with notice of rights and access to counsel upon apprehension. Upon apprehension, unaccompanied alien children are provided with an interview, screening, orientation, and notice of their rights under the Immigration and Nationality Act, including relief from removal, access to counsel, and complaint mechanisms. The Secretary ensures language access for these children. The Secretary ensures language access for unaccompanied alien children by providing orientation and notices of rights in English and the 5 most common native languages spoken by the children in custody. Confidentiality of information gathered during care, custody, and follow-up services is maintained. The Secretary must provide follow-up services to unaccompanied alien children while maintaining confidentiality of information, only disclosing it in writing and if in the child's best interest or authorized by the child or an approved sponsor. Additionally, the Secretary must adopt fundamental child protection policies and procedures. The Secretary must adopt child protection policies and procedures, including reliable age determinations, deferring removal for life-threatening risks, and ensuring physical separation of unaccompanied alien children in detention. The Repatriation and Reintegration Program aims to support the safe return and integration of unaccompanied alien children with the help of various government and non-governmental organizations. The Repatriation and Reintegration Program focuses on returning unaccompanied alien children to their home countries or last habitual residence, and includes efforts to improve repatriation and reintegration programs. The Administrator of the Agency for International Development is required to submit a report on these efforts to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees. The Secretary is authorized to transfer funds for these purposes. The Secretary and the Secretary of Health and Human Services will transfer necessary amounts from U.S. Customs and Border Protection to carry out specified duties. A detailed expenditure plan must be submitted 15 days before any transfer to the Senate and House Committees on Appropriations.
